mn67:17.1: The gharial is a large crocodilian of the Ganges. The adult male has a distinctive “pot” (_ghara_) at the tip of its snout, from which it takes the name gharial. The Pali _kumbhīla_ and Sanskrit _kumbhīra_ likewise stem from _kumbha_, “pot”. Gharials can be seen breaking water to swallow fish, their long toothy snouts making them an apt symbol for gluttony.
mn67:19.1: The _susukā_ is said to be a carnivorous fish (_caṇḍamaccha_). It is possibly a shark, of which several species are found in the Ganges. But it may also be the goonch, descriptively known as the “giant devil catfish”, which possesses a terrifying toothed maw. It is said to devour the corpses ritually disposed of in the Ganges, and even to consume living people. The Sanskrit form _śuṣkala_ is said to mean both a species of fish and also “flesh”.
